What Happens?

First, you deposit your recyclables into a recycling hub, a public recycling bin or your kerbside recycling bin according to your area's schedule. Garbage collectors will collect recyclables from recycling hubs and public bins at a set schedule, kerbside bins (blue bins and wheelie bins with yellow lids) will be picked up on a weekly schedule based on the area you live. This will likely be done by a garbage truck at late or early hours of the day so they don't disturb traffic as much.

Second, unrecyclable items such as plastic bags, clothing, batteries and food scraps are removed by hand from the collected recycling. The trash is then autonomously sorted by machines at a facility. Paper and cardboards is removed with a vibrating machine while metals are removed with magnets or an eddy current. Optical scanners identify different plastics. After this all that should be left is glass which is sorted by colour. Once everything is sorted, it is sold to national and international buyers who will then make use of the product.

Lastly, the buyer of the product will use the recycled materials. Glass will usually be re-made back into bottles and jars, it could also be turned into products known as 'glassphalt' and 'glasscrete', to be used in road construction. paper and cardboard can be made into newsprint, writing paper, tissue, egg cartons etc. Plastic can be made back into almost anything while metals will be turned into food packaging, wire or building materials.
